comments.body:
This is just a goimports change; not an attempt to really alias it. Do you really want me to change the default alias here or you were just disagreeing with my the idea that I explicitly chose one (and it was v1)?

By the way, this is the motivation for https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/77407 ; the change has nothing to do with this PR but is inevitably discussed.

Standard style is to call this package corev1

https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=corev1&type=

With modules, many editors explicitly adding the v1 alias to the front to make it more obvious to people that this is a v1 package and not a v1 version of the core package, but most places this is imported we call it corev1

FWIW it looks like that is not quite the case. I'm happy to change it but this was why #77045 got created; `v1` and `corev1` get used roughly equally, but unaliased is about 5x as popular.

My approach on #77407 was to run goimports on a bunch of files to make them consistent but that would have pushed the `v1` alias. If you prefer the corev1 I can do that instead. (It is the goimports that adds the v1 alias, not the editor itself though I had heard that as well but confirmed goimports itself is the perpetrator)

```
$ rg '^[\s]*v1 "k8s.io/api/core/v1"' | wc -l
     220
$ rg '^[\s]*corev1 "k8s.io/api/core/v1"' | wc -l
     257
$ rg '^[\s]*"k8s.io/api/core/v1"' | wc -l
    1130
```
We don't need the test "should install plugin without kubelet restart" anymore, it's exactly the same as this test

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +222,226 @@	It("should be mountable when non-attachable", func() {
		driver := "dummy"
		driverInstallAs := driver + "-" + suffix

		By(fmt.Sprintf("installing flexvolume %s on node %s as %s", path.Join(driverDir, driver), node.Name, driverInstallAs))

comments.body: Do we have tests where the master is on a higher version than the nodes?
Not sure, I did a quick search and didn't find any tests that get master version. The cluster upgrade test has a function to verify the master version, and my implementation is based on that
Ok, I was worried about a case where it would install the flex driver on the node based off of the master version.  But it looks like that's not the case.
Not sure I'm a fan of comments interleaved with code in the same line.
The comment is mainly to clarify the parameter name, and is used in several places in the code base AFAIK.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +175,179 @@
		By(fmt.Sprintf("installing flexvolume %s on node %s as %s", path.Join(driverDir, driver), node.Name, driverInstallAs))
		installFlex(&node, "k8s", driverInstallAs, path.Join(driverDir, driver), true /* restart */)

		testFlexVolume(driverInstallAs, cs, config, f, clean)

comments.body: Again not sure I like the interleaved comments. And this one should probably read "skip restart", in any case.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +215,219 @@
		By(fmt.Sprintf("installing flexvolume %s on node %s as %s", path.Join(driverDir, driver), node.Name, driverInstallAs))
		installFlex(&node, "k8s", driverInstallAs, path.Join(driverDir, driver), false /* restart */)

		testFlexVolume(driverInstallAs, cs, config, f, clean)

comments.body: Can you make the content include some generated id, like the test namespace name, so that we can distinguish between different test instances?

it could be even better to make the flex driver name include something generated (it is slightly easier too). e.g. test instance abcd installs driver dummy-abcd, test qwer dummy-qwer, so test instance will be evident from that. And parallel or subsequent tests won't conflict
